claim: Sitting close to the television can cause eyestrain.

supporting.text: Prolonged focus on a nearby screen can lead to eye muscle fatigue, contributing to eyestrain.

attacks.text: Prolonged focus on a nearby screen can lead to eye muscle fatigue, contributing to eyestrain.
Modern screens emit less harmful blue light and have flicker-free technology, reducing the risk of eyestrain.
Even with modern screens, prolonged focus without breaks still causes eye muscle fatigue.
Eyestrain is primarily caused by poor lighting or improper screen brightness, not proximity.
Proximity can exacerbate poor lighting or brightness issues, indirectly contributing to eyestrain.

supporting.text: Sitting too close to the television may reduce blinking frequency, causing dry eyes and discomfort.

attacks.text: Sitting too close to the television may reduce blinking frequency, causing dry eyes and discomfort.
Modern televisions emit less harmful light and have features like blue light filters, reducing the risk of eyestrain.
Even with modern features, prolonged close viewing can still lead to eye fatigue due to sustained focus.
Blinking frequency is more affected by content engagement (e.g., action scenes) than viewing distance.
Close viewing distance increases the likelihood of reduced blinking regardless of content, as the eyes work harder to focus.

supporting.text: Modern televisions emit blue light, which at close range can increase visual stress and eyestrain.

attacks.text: Modern televisions emit blue light, which at close range can increase visual stress and eyestrain.
Blue light filters and screen settings on modern televisions significantly reduce the risk of eyestrain, even at close range.
Many blue light filters are not fully effective, and prolonged exposure can still contribute to eyestrain over time.
Eyestrain from sitting close to televisions is primarily due to prolonged focus rather than blue light emission.
Blue light has been scientifically shown to disrupt circadian rhythms and increase eye fatigue, supporting its role in eyestrain.

supporting.text: Viewing a screen from an inappropriate distance can disrupt the eye's natural focal adjustment, leading to strain.

attacks.text: Viewing a screen from an inappropriate distance can disrupt the eye's natural focal adjustment, leading to strain.
Modern screens emit less harmful light and have better resolution, reducing the risk of eyestrain regardless of distance.
Even with modern screens, prolonged close viewing can still cause temporary discomfort due to reduced blinking and fixed focal length.
Eyestrain is more commonly caused by prolonged screen time rather than viewing distance.
Viewing distance exacerbates eyestrain when combined with prolonged screen time, making it a contributing factor.

supporting.text: The American Academy of Ophthalmology states that sitting close to screens does not cause permanent damage but can result in temporary eyestrain.

attacks.text: The American Academy of Ophthalmology states that sitting close to screens does not cause permanent damage but can result in temporary eyestrain.
Studies show that prolonged screen time, regardless of distance, is the primary cause of eyestrain, not proximity.

The American Academy of Ophthalmology's statement is based on general cases and does not account for individuals with pre-existing vision conditions who may experience more severe eyestrain from sitting close.
Children often sit closer to screens due to their shorter focal length needs, and there is no evidence that this causes more eyestrain than in adults.
Children's eyes are still developing, and excessive close-up screen exposure may contribute to myopia progression, which is a form of long-term eyestrain.

supporting.text: High screen brightness at close proximity can overwhelm the eyes' light adaptation mechanisms, causing discomfort.

attacks.text: High screen brightness at close proximity can overwhelm the eyes' light adaptation mechanisms, causing discomfort.
Modern TVs and screens often have automatic brightness adjustment features that reduce glare and prevent overwhelming light exposure.
Automatic brightness adjustment may not always respond quickly or accurately enough to prevent temporary discomfort in high-contrast scenes.
Eyestrain from screen brightness is temporary and does not cause long-term damage to vision.
Repeated temporary eyestrain can lead to chronic discomfort and may contribute to long-term vision problems like digital eye strain syndrome.
